title: Chelsea vs Manchester United live updates
body_text:
How Sam Kerr goal won Chelsea the Women’s FA Cup with victory over Manchester United
Summary
Chelsea beat Manchester United 1-0 on Sunday to lift their third consecutive Women’s FA Cup, with Sam Kerr’s second-half goal proving the difference in a closely-fought affair.
United started the game brightly, which was played at Wembley Stadium in front of a world-record attendance for a domestic women’s game.
Marc Skinner’s side had a goal disallowed for offside after less than 30 seconds and had a strong appeal for a penalty turned down later in the half. But VAR —which was being used for the first time in an English women’s domestic club game — judged the foul to have occurred just outside the area.
The introduction of Pernille Harder in the 57th minute changed the match for Chelsea, as she assisted Kerr for the game’s winning goal.
Signing off
It was a day the record crowd will remember for a long time. Sam Kerr's goal was the difference between two evenly-matched teams.
Views from the stands: Ramu & Cydney
Ramu (Manchester United fan): For a team playing their first cup final against serial winners like Chelsea, although we are disappointed, we are immensly proud of the team and excited for everything moving forwards.
Cydney (Chelsea fan): There isn't much to say except the better team won at the end of the day, in the first half we were poor but whatever Emma Hayes said worked. Up the blues!
Hayes' half-time fire-up
Chelsea manager Emma Hayes praised how her side fought back into the game.
"You can't underestimate the game accumulation, we looked so tired in the first half. We had to kick each other at half time," she said.
"We know how to stay in a game and even if we weren't at our best we have to work out how to change it.
"We had to possess the ball better and then find the quality in the final third.
"It's a coach's nightmare. We don't do the kick-off properly and then the first, second and third phases were all off."
(All photos by Getty Images)
It has not been raining...
... well hasn't been raining water at least.
(All photos by Getty Images)
Heroes to a generation
The moment Chelsea lifted the trophy on the pitch...
... forgive the rogue cameraman.
(All photos by Getty Images)
Reflections from runner-up's manager
Manchester United manager Marc Skinner spoke to BBC One after the game.
"We switch off in one moment, there's space to Sam [Kerr] to run in to which we haven't given her all game," said Skinner.
"I'm proud of the girls today, they are hungry. Their position is what we want to take. We are a young, hungry team. I need to find the pieces to make sure we challenge all the time.
"Chelsea have done hardly anything in the game, but they are winners for a reason, they find that tiny little gap.
"I want to thank all the fans, they have been magnificent.
"We won't dwell on this, it fuels us... this will be us in future."
Moments to remember
Chelsea lift the trophy again on the presentation on the pitch, champagne is flying everywhere, fantastic scenes.
Your 2023 WFA Cup winners
Repeat offenders. They've played here more than Stamford Bridge. Three consecutive WFA Cups.
(All photos by Getty Images)
United post-game huddle
Marc Skinner addressing his runners-up after the game.
(All photos by Getty Images)
The Champions lift the trophy
Millie Bright and Magdalena Eriksson share the honour of lifting the trophy as the Chelsea fans in attendance celebrate.
Kerr's goal... and the flip!
A moment those Chelsea fans in attendance will never forget.
On their way to glory
Chelsea's players are walking up the famous steps to go and receive their winners medals.
Words from the game changer
Pernille Harder's introduction changed the game for Chelsea, providing the assist for Sam Kerr's goal.
"It's amazing to win titles. A full Wembley is amazing," said Harder.
"Of course, it's sad when you are out for so long [with an injury] but you come back with motivation and hunger.
"It's amazing to come back for this game and be involved in a win.
"Chelsea means a lot to me. I've had so many great memories here."
Runners-up
The Manchester United players are receiving their runners-up medals from Prince William.
This is what it means
(All photos by Getty Images)
Sam Kerr reflects on the game
Match winner Sam Kerr provided her thoughts after the game, speaking to the BBC:
"We didn't have our best game but we just push through and that's the sign of a great team," said the Australian striker.
"I'd be lying if I said it was all me. It was about the team."
When given the player of the match award, Kerr said she felt others had played better than her but will "take it on behalf of the team."
View from the stands: Gavin
After a brilliant start to the game, it's a hard one to take for the United fans and players, but there is plenty of positives to take.
"I'm proud of United, they were exceptionally good in the first half, I think in the latter stages of the second half they become lagged and tired and gaps started to appear," said Gavin.
"Chelsea are a machine and they just started to grow in confidence, United came on strong in injury time but it was just too much."
My player of the match
Sam Kerr was awarded the official player of the match award and whilst she was excellent, Pernille Harder is the match winner.
The Denmark international changed the game, threatening twice as a potential goalscorer and assister, before Kerr tucked her chance away to win the game.
FT: Chelsea 1-0 Manchester United
FT: Chelsea 1-0 Manchester United
Chelsea hang on! Sam Kerr is the match winner!
Chelsea become the third team to secure three consecutive WFA Cup's in the competitions history.
